intro: Salix semicordata, commonly known as the heartleaf willow, is a deciduous shrub native to the arid regions of western North America. It is characterized by its distinctive heart-shaped leaves, which are typically 2–5 inches long and have a rough, hairy texture. The plant produces catkins in early spring, which are its primary means of wind pollination. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in desert scrub and along riverbanks. Salix semicordata is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to stabilize soil in harsh environments.
